paper_abstract: The perspective 3-point problem, also known as pose estimation, has its origins in camera calibration and is of importance in many fields: for example, computer animation, automation, image analysis and robotics. One line of activity involves formulating it mathematically in terms of finding the solution to a quartic equation. However, in general, the equation does not have a unique solution, and in some situations there are no solutions at all. Here, we present a new approach to the solution of the problem; this involves closer scrutiny of the coefficients of the polynomial, in order to understand how many solutions there will be for a given set of problem parameters. We find that, if the control points are equally spaced, there are four positive solutions to the problem at 25 % of all available spatial locations for the control-point combinations, and two positive solutions at the remaining 75 %.
paper_title: Mathematical Analysis of the Multisolution Phenomenon in the P3P Problem
